review.title: Controversy and Sentiment in Online News
review.abstract: How do news sources tackle controversial issues? In this work, we take a data-driven approach to understand how controversy interplays with emotional expression and biased language in the news. We begin by introducing a new dataset of controversial and non-controversial terms collected using crowdsourcing. Then, focusing on 15 major U.S. news outlets, we compare millions of articles discussing controversial and non-controversial issues over a span of 7 months. We find that in general, when it comes to controversial issues, the use of negative affect and biased language is prevalent, while the use of strong emotion is tempered. We also observe many differences across news sources. Using these findings, we show that we can indicate to what extent an issue is controversial, by comparing it with other issues in terms of how they are portrayed across different media.

sections.heading: 1. INTRODUCTION
sections.text: One of the most important functions of the news media is to serve as a place for critical review and presentation of information on social, political, economic and ideological issues of the day. Many of these questions are controversial in the sense that they provoke arguments in which people express strongly conflicting opinions. [10] For this reason, journalists often have to take special precautions and make careful language choices when writing about controversial topics. This can often manifest itself as different types of use of language, for example news sources will often use a number of terms to signal that a controversy exists, such as "outcry," "riot" and "uproar." It has been theorized that journalists become vulnerable to the ideologies, attitudes and pressures of their organization, as well as unspoken rules and norms. These submissions can influence the specific language used to discuss controversial topics within a particular news source.

sections.text: The data was provided by NewsCred, which aggregates news content from thousands of news sources and provides it via an API (further described in Diakopoulos et al. [7]). We selected 15 high-volume NewsCred sources and looked at their articles over the period from March to September 2013. sections.heading: 5. CONTROVERSY AND SENTIMENT
sections.text: Using the data sets described above, we explore the vocabulary used in articles mentioning controversial / non-controversial topics, using a set of lexical resources associated with sentiment and bias. The general methodology is to look at every word w in our vocabulary of 462 topics and every media source s in our list of 15 news media. Then, collect all articles in the sources that contain the word w, eliminate duplicate and nearly duplicate articles (typically a by-product of articles that have multiple URLs) and combine all articles into a topical (and very large) superarticle for analysis. The analysis consists of examining this content using a lexical resource, counting the proportion of words that correspond to a specific category in the lexical resource. sections.heading: 7. DISCUSSION
sections.text: In this study, we found that controversial topics are often framed by negative emotions. Many of the terms that have been discussed controversially often relate to social problems and violence, such as firearms, fighting, crime, victims and shootings, or war. There may not be as many ways to discuss some of these topics in a non-negative light. However, other terms could be viewed in a negative, positive, or even neutral light depending on the context in which they are used, for example, terms like health, safety, or jobs. However, since these words often raise larger ideological issues of government spending, privacy, or the economy, frames may emerge that are more antagonistic. Instead of highlighting the positive aspects of one's own perspective, an author may choose to highlight the negative aspects of opposing views. Furthermore, we found that controversial topics also contain less strongly emotional words.
